intro: Gilia collina var. grantii, commonly known as the Grant's gilia, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States. It belongs to the family Polemoniaceae and is characterized by its striking blue to violet flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or gravelly soils in dry, open habitats. It produces slender, branched stems and has narrow, lance-shaped leaves. The flowers bloom in late spring to early summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies.
